children.name: find out
children.definition: to get information about sth, either by chance or by deliberately trying to get it:tìm ra, phát hiện ra
examples: ▪ ‘Do you have these shoes in size 8?’ ‘I’m not sure - I’ll just go and find out.’
▪ When we found out the price we were shocked.
find out what/ where/ whether etc
▪ I’ll go and find out which platform the train leaves from.
▪ Dad was really mad at me when he found out where I’d been.
find out about
▪ He’s trying to find out about Japanese classes in the area.
find out something/ find something out
▪ Could you find out his address for me, please?
▪ ‘John’s been married twice.’ ‘How did you find that out?’
find out (that)
▪ She found out that her husband was having an affair.

children.name: discover
children.definition: to find sth out, especially something that is surprising or sth that is difficult to find out.Discoveris more formal thanfindout:phát hiện, khám phá ra
examples: ▪ Fire officers are still trying to discover the cause of the fire.

children.name: discover (that)
examples: ▪ I began to learn the guitar, and discovered that I was pretty good at it.
▪ She discovered the job wasn’t as easy as it might seem.

children.name: discover how/ why/ what etc
examples: ▪ They never discovered who the murderer was.

children.name: hear
children.definition: to know about sth because sb has told you, you have read about it, seen it on television etc:nghe nói
examples: ▪ ‘Nina’s quit her job.’ ‘Yes, so I’ve heard.’
hear about
▪ How did you hear about our company?
▪ We’ve heard such a lot about you from our daughter.
hear (that)
▪ I hear you’re moving to Toronto.
hear whether/if
▪ When will you hear whether you’ve got the job?
hear what/ why/ how etc
▪ I suppose you’ve heard what happened?

children.name: see
children.definition: especiallyspokento get the information that you want by going somewhere to look, or by doing sth and noticing what happens:xem xem, tìm xem, coi xem
examples: ▪ ‘Is he ready yet?’ ‘I don’t know - I’ll go and see.’
see if/ whether
▪ See if the rice is done while you’re in the kitchen, will you?
see how/ where/ what etc
▪ Can you see who’s at the door?
▪ Let’s see what happens if we add some oil.

children.name: find
children.definition: especiallywrittento find out a fact or find out that something is true, especially byaskingquestions:phát hiện ra

children.name: find (that)
examples: We found that, despite their poverty, very few people wanted to leave the area.
Researchers found that smokers were more likely to get depressed than non-smokers.

children.name: be told
children.definition: to find out about sth because sb tells you:được biết
examples: be told (that)
▪ He was told that Anna had left some time ago.
▪ Visitors have been told the building will be used as a museum.
so I’m toldspoken
▪ ‘Is it true that she’s moving to Hollywood?’ ‘So I’m told.’

children.name: learn
children.definition: to find out sth because sb tells you, you read it somewhere etc:biết
examples: ▪ I doubt if we will ever learn the truth.

children.name: learn of/about
examples: ▪ She learned of her mother’s death when it was announced on the radio.

children.name: learn (that)
examples: ▪ Several months ago, McNair learned that he had cancer.

children.name: gather U
children.definition: gather to know a piece of information because that is what you hear people saying and not because you have been told it directly:nghe nói

children.name: gather (that)
examples: ▪ I gather you’ve decided not to resign after all.
▪ Despite my limited Spanish, I gathered that there was a problem with my passport.

children.name: from what sb can gatheraccording to what I have found out
examples: ▪ From what I can gather, there has been fighting further down the valley.

children.name: come to sb’s attention
children.definition: /notice formal if sth such as a problem or a mistake comes to sb’s attention or notice, that person finds out about it, especially because someone else tells them about it:được chú ý
examples: ▪ Illegal trading first came to the attention of top management in late April.

children.name: come to sb’s attention/ notice that
examples: ▪ It has come to my notice that your account is overdrawn by £200.

children.name: hear on the grapevine
children.definition: hear through/ on the grapevine to find out about sth because the information has been passed on from one person to another in conversation: nghe đồn
examples: ▪ ‘How did you find out she was leaving?’ ‘I heard it through the grapevine.’
hear through/ on the grapevine that
▪ I heard on the grapevine that Josie and Tom are expecting a baby.

children.name: to find out sth new or secret
find out
children.definition: phát hiện
examples: ▪ He just had to hope he’d get away with it and that nobody would find out.
▪ She doesn’t want people to find out her age.
▪ You read her diary? Just make sure she never finds out!

children.name: find out what/ why/ how etc
examples: ▪ Dad was furious when he found out where I was living.

children.name: find out about
examples: ▪ It’s a surprise party, so I don’t want her to find out about it.

children.name: find out (that)
examples: ▪ It was three months before my parents found out I’d been going out with Peter.

children.name: find sb outUK find out someone’s secret
examples: ▪ It won’t work. Someone’s bound to find you out eventually.

children.name: uncover
children.definition: /unearth to find out information that has been deliberately kept secret, especially while you are studying or examining a particular subject:tìm ra, phát hiện
examples: ▪ Detectives have uncovered a plan to smuggle illegal weapons into the country.
▪ Lawyers unearthed evidence that he held several bank accounts.

children.name: dig up
children.definition: to find out information by searching carefully for it, especially information about someone’s past that they have deliberately tried to keep secret:đào bới

children.name: dig something up/dig up something
examples: ▪ I wanted to dig a few more facts up for my article.

children.name: dig up dirt on somebodyfind out something bad about someone
examples: ▪ Politicians try to dig up dirt on their opponents.

children.name: dig something up on somebody
examples: ▪ He wanted as much evidence as could be dug up on the girl.

children.name: get at U
children.definition: get at to find sth out, especially the truth about a situation, or facts that sb has tried to hide:
examples: ▪ It’s hard to get at the facts when people are afraid to speak out.
▪ He was a good reporter, who wanted to get at the truth and present it without bias.

children.name: get wind of
children.definition: informal to find out about a situation or sth that is going to happen, especially when it is supposed to be secret:nghe phong phanh
examples: ▪ Reporters somehow got wind of the fact that Carr was going to be arrested.

children.name: get wise to
children.definition: informal to find out about something such as a trick or an illegal activity:nhận biết (một trò lừa, sự bất chính)
examples: ▪ The police parked an empty patrol car there to reduce speeding, but drivers got wise to it pretty quickly.

children.name: to find out the exact cause of sth
determine
children.definition: to find out the exact details or facts about sth, especially by using technical methods and equipment:xác định
examples: ▪ ‘Web police’ are often able to determine the exact source of unwanted mailings on the Internet.

children.name: determine what/ why/ how etc
examples: ▪ Quizzes are used to determine how much material students have learned.

children.name: determine that
examples: ▪ A survey of traffic accidents determined that seat belts reduced serious injuries by up to 90%.

children.name: establish
children.definition: to find out facts that will prove how sth happened or what caused it:xác định
examples: ▪ We haven’t yet established the cause of the accident.

children.name: establish that
examples: ▪ It was quickly established that several members of the crew had been negligent.

children.name: establish how/ where/ why etc
examples: ▪ They are carrying out research to establish exactly why so many species of songbird are disappearing.

children.name: identify
children.definition: to find out exactly what the cause or origin of sth is:xác định
examples: ▪ After years of research, scientists have identified the virus that is responsible for the disease.
▪ Experts are examining the wreckage, but the cause of the accident has not yet been identified.

children.name: pinpoint
children.definition: to find out exactly what sth is, when sth happened, or what exactly is causing sth:xác định
examples: ▪ Investigators are trying to pinpoint the cause of the fire.
▪ Mechanics are having difficulty pinpointing the problem.

children.name: pinpoint what/ how/ when etc
examples: ▪ The test is meant to pinpoint which types of jobs you are suited for.

children.name: to find out info from sb
find out
children.definition: to find out information from someone by asking them questions or by forcing them to tell you: tìm hiểu
examples: ▪ Will you see if you can find anything out about Sandy?
▪ ‘Did you find out her views on the subject?’ ‘No, she wouldn’t tell me.’
find out what/ how/ when etc
▪ He asked me to find out what your plans are after you leave.

children.name: get sth out of
children.definition: informal to find out a particular piece of information from sb, especially by forcing them to tell you:tra hỏi
examples: ▪ Jed admitted he’d been at the scene, but that’s all I could get out of him.
▪ We’ll get the truth out of her sooner or later.

children.name: get information
children.definition: to find out sth from a person, a book, the Internet etc: kiếm thông tin
examples: ▪ To get more information, telephone or contact us on our website.
▪ You will be able to get most of the information you need from the school library.

children.name: get information about/ on
examples: ▪ I’ve written to the tourist information centre to get some information about the area.

children.name: extract
children.definition: formal to find out information from sb who does not want to give it, by asking them questions or by using physical force:moi tin
examples: ▪ Police questioned the prisoner for several hours, but were unable to extract any further information.

children.name: extract sth from sb
examples: ▪ The court ruled that her confession had been unlawfully extracted from her.

children.name: worm sth out of
children.definition: sb to find out information from sb who is unwilling to give it, especially by being clever, making them feel they can trust you etc:thuyết phục ai nói ra
examples: ▪ He didn’t want to tell me her name but I managed to worm it out of him.

children.name: drag sth out of
children.definition: to get information from sb who does not want to tell you it, especially by asking a lot of questions:cạy miệng
examples: ▪ If she doesn’t want to tell you, there’s no point in trying to drag it out of her.

children.name: to try to find out sth private or personal
snoop
children.definition: to try to find out about sb’s private affairs, especially by secretly looking in their house, examining their possessions etc:rình mò
examples: ▪ Bob caught her snooping through the papers on his desk.

children.name: snoop on
examples: ▪ Technology is making it easier to snoop on just about anybody.

children.name: snoop around/ aboutBritish
examples: ▪ What are you doing snooping around in my room?

children.name: pry
children.definition: to try to find out about sb’s private life by asking a lot of personal questions in a way that people find rude or annoying:soi mói
examples: My son hasn’t given us a reason for his divorce, and we don’t want to pry.

children.name: pry into
examples: Employers shouldn’t try to pry into what a person does in the privacy of their own home.

children.name: nose around
children.definition: / aboutUK  informal to look around a place, especially sb’s home or office, to try to find out things that do not really concern you:sục sạo
examples: ▪ The kids were nosing around in the attic and found a box of old photos.

children.name: nose around an office/ room/house etc
examples: ▪ I got suspicious when I found him nosing around my office early one morning.

children.name: discovery
children.definition: sth such as a new fact or method that someone has found out, either accidentally or as a result of careful examination or questions:khám phá, phát hiện
examples: ▪ At first I did not realize the importance of my discovery.

children.name: discovery that
examples: ▪ An investigation was ordered after the discovery that $89,000 was missing from the account.

children.name: discovery about
examples: ▪ The depletion of the ozone layer has been one of the most dramatic discoveries about our planet in recent years.

children.name: finding
children.definition: the information that sb has found out as a result of examining sth carefully:phát hiện
examples: ▪ One of the findings was that many cases of ‘stomach flu’ are caused by improper cooking of food.
▪ The police force has had its image severely battered by the commission’s findings.
